results.title: 19 Killed in New York City’s Deadliest Fire in Decades
results.abstract: Nine children were among those who died when a space heater malfunctioned in a Bronx apartment building, city officials said.
results.byline: By Ashley Southall, Grace Ashford and Chelsia Rose Marcius

multimedia.caption: Firefighters found victims on every floor of a 19th-story Bronx building after a blaze started Sunday morning, the fire commissioner said.
multimedia.copyright: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times

results.title: ‘We Were Just Trying to Breathe’: Frantic Rush to Escape the Smoke
results.abstract: Residents who survived the Bronx inferno on Sunday described a quiet morning that suddenly was overtaken by terror and tragedy.
results.byline: By Michael Wilson and Chelsia Rose Marcius

multimedia.caption: A firefighter carries a child out of the deadly fire in the West Bronx on Sunday.
multimedia.copyright: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times

results.title: Novak Djokovic Can Remain in Australia, Judge Rules
results.abstract: The court ordered the government to release him from detention and restore a visa. But Australian officials suggested they may make a new attempt to cancel it.
results.byline: By Damien Cave and Matthew Futterman

multimedia.caption: Novak Djokovic before a Davis Cup match in Austria last year.

results.title: Disruption, Dismay, Dissent: Americans Grapple With Omicron’s Rise
results.abstract: The variant is spreading fast. For some, it is causing milder illness. But its distinct qualities have left Americans making a new set of calculations.

multimedia.caption: Covid testing in New Orleans on Wednesday.
multimedia.copyright: Emily Kask for The New York Times

results.title: Early Data Hints at Omicron’s Potential Toll Across America
results.abstract: In the cities that were among the first to experience rapid rises in Covid cases due to Omicron, serious outcomes including I.C.U. stays and deaths are following case curves upward.
results.byline: By Lauren Leatherby and Eleanor Lutz

results.title: In Ukraine Conflict, Putin Relies on a Promise That Ultimately Wasn’t
results.abstract: The current confrontation turns partly on what, if any, commitments Secretary of State James A. Baker III made about NATO’s expansion in the waning days of the Cold War.

multimedia.caption: James A. Baker III has said that in the end, he did not rule out NATO expansion into Eastern Europe in a treaty signed after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
multimedia.copyright: Michael Temchine for The New York Times

results.title: Russia Warns That U.S. Doesn’t Understand Its Goals on Ukraine
results.abstract: Before the two countries met amid rising tensions over Ukraine, a senior Russian official and the U.S. Secretary of State set a pessimistic tone.
results.byline: By Anton Troianovski and David E. Sanger

multimedia.caption: The Russian deputy foreign minister, Sergei A. Ryabkov, in June. He will meet with U.S. negotiators in talks aimed at de-escalating tensions on Ukraine.

results.title: Bob Saget, Comic Who Portrayed Danny Tanner on ‘Full House,’ Dies at 65
results.abstract: The actor, who had also hosted “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” was found dead in an Orlando hotel room while on tour.
results.byline: By Jesus Jiménez and Alan Yuhas

multimedia.caption: In contrast to his squeaky-clean image on “Full House” and “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” Bob Saget delighted in raunchy, profanity-laden stand-up routines.
multimedia.copyright: Mike Coppola/Getty Images For Tribeca Festival

results.title: Your Head of H.R. Is Now Basically the School Nurse
results.abstract: Vaccine mandates. Boosters. Exemptions. Testing protocol. Just a handful of public health questions that human resources departments now have to answer.

multimedia.caption: Gia Ganesh, the chief of human resources at Florence Healthcare, now also has to focus on the physical health and safety of the employees.
multimedia.copyright: Audra Melton for The New York Times

results.title: What New Yorkers See in This Portrait of the Mayor’s Mother
results.abstract: Dorothy Mae Adams-Streeter posed for a portrait at her 75th birthday party. Her image, floating in a brandy snifter, has a powerful resonance.

multimedia.caption: Mayor Eric Adams clasped a photo of his mother, Dorothy Mae Adams-Streeter, after he was sworn into office. The portrait was done in a style once popular among working-class New Yorkers.

results.title: After 4 Killings, ‘Officer of the Year’ Is Still on the Job
results.abstract: A Pennsylvania state trooper was returned to duty following three investigations by his own agency. A fourth inquiry is underway.
results.byline: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder and David D. Kirkpatrick

results.title: ‘Jeopardy!’ Keeps Seeing Winning Streaks. Champions Ponder Why.
results.abstract: Amy Schneider isn’t the only one on a roll. Just a dozen players have won 10 or more games, half of those in the past five years, and a quarter in this season alone.

multimedia.caption: Amy Schneider — whose “Jeopardy!” winnings recently surpassed $1 million — is the third contestant this season with a long winning streak.

results.title: Overlooked No More: Theresa Hak Kyung Cha, Artist and Author Who Explored Identity
results.abstract: She was murdered after the publication of her first novel, “Dictee,” a challenging exploration of Korean history and immigrant life that inspires Asian American writers today.

multimedia.caption: Theresa Hak Kyung Cha in about 1980, when she traveled to Seoul to work on a film project.

results.title: Tracing a Los Angeles Treasure: Its Glorious Sprawl of Sushi
results.abstract: Few locales outside Japan can equal the variety, skill and creativity served at the city’s countless sushi counters.

results.title: As More Teachers’ Unions Push for Remote Schooling, Parents Worry. So Do Democrats.
results.abstract: Chicago teachers have voted to go remote. Other unions are agitating for change. For Democrats, who promised to keep schools open, the tensions are a distinctly unwelcome development.

results.title: A Soldier Sent a Letter to His Mom in 1945. It Was Just Delivered.

results.title: A Giant Telescope Grows in Space
results.abstract: Everything is going great for the James Webb Space Telescope. So far.
results.byline: By Dennis Overbye and Joey Roulette

multimedia.caption: An artist’s concept of the fully deployed and unfolded James Webb Space Telescope, which is currently on its way to a spot called L2, where it will orbit the sun. It is now 600,000 miles from Earth.

results.title: Conflict Quickly Emerges Between Top Prosecutor and Police Commissioner

results.title: A Custom Mercury, With a Batmobile in Its Family Tree, Heads to Auction

multimedia.caption: The Hirohata Merc, a Mercury custom built nearly 70 years ago, is expected to fetch at least $1 million at an auction this month.

results.title: Jim Jordan Refuses to Cooperate With Jan. 6 Panel

results.title: Noncitizens’ Right to Vote Becomes Law in New York City
results.abstract: Starting next year, 800,000 legal permanent residents will be eligible to vote in municipal elections.
des_facet: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)

multimedia.caption: Legal residents will be able to vote in primary and general elections for citywide contests, like those for mayor and public advocate, as well as in local races for City Council members and borough presidents.

results.title: Nearly 6,000 Detained Amid Unrest in Kazakhstan
results.abstract: Protests that began last weekend over a hike in fuel prices spread across the country, leaving at least 2,000 injured, government officials said. Dozens of deaths also appeared likely.

multimedia.caption: The mayor’s office building was burned during demonstrations last week in Almaty, Kazakhstan.

results.title: Cliff Collapses on Boaters in Brazil, Killing 10
results.abstract: The tragedy in Minas Gerais state gripped the nation because it was captured on videos that showed an immense slab of rock smashing into pleasure boats.

results.title: Stephen Lawrence, Whose Music Enriched ‘Sesame Street,’ Dies at 82
results.abstract: He composed the title song of the landmark album “Free to Be … You and Me.” He then moved on to Big Bird and friends.

multimedia.caption: The songwriter Stephen Lawrence in an undated photo. He won three Daytime Emmy Awards for his work on “Sesame Street.”

results.title: Prehistoric Rock Art ‘Irreparably Damaged’ by Vandals, Officials Say
results.abstract: Geometric rock carvings that are believed to be at least 3,000 years old were scratched with names and dates at Big Bend National Park in Texas.

multimedia.caption: At Big Bend National Park in Texas, vandals permanently damaged prehistoric rock art that featured abstract designs that were created thousands of years ago, officials said.

results.title: Freelance Writer Accuses The Atlantic of Defamation
results.abstract: A lawsuit by Ruth Shalit Barrett centers on the magazine’s retraction of her article in 2020 about wealthy parents seeking Ivy League admissions for their children through sports.

multimedia.caption: In her lawsuit, Ruth Shalit Barrett accused The Atlantic and Donald Peck, its top print editor at the time, of smearing her reputation.
